sentence: The analytical sensitivities of the three PCRs were determined following the methods shown in Fig. 1.
The detection limit of C-PCR was found 120 pg/reaction (3 × 104 copies/reaction), while N-PCR and Q-PCR assays could detect as few as 0.012 pg/reaction (3 copies/reaction; Ct = 37) (Fig. 2).

N-PCR and Q-PCR assays using categories (b) and (c) as DNA templates (Fig. 1) showed that detection limits of both the N-PCR and Q-PCR were 42 organisms/ml (Ct = 36.9), which corresponded to 10−7 dilution of S.

Determination of diagnostic performance ability of blood culture, N-PCR and Q-PCR assays considering clinically diagnosed typhoid fever (CDTF) cases (n = 110) positive by any of the test methods as standarda

b, c
p < 0.0001 using McNemer test

d
p > 0.1 using McNemer test
The distributions of Ct values of 110 samples from CDTF cases were shown in Fig. 3.
The standard curve (Fig. 2b) was used to calculate the bacterial DNA load among the study patients.
Analytical sensitivities of both N-PCR and Q-PCR assays were similar (3 copies/reaction) (Fig. 2).

Although higher copy number (median, 3160 copies/ml) of bacterial DNA was observed by Q-PCR assay in blood culture negative cases (n = 57), the higher rate (60 %) of antibiotic intake among the study population might lead to negative results in blood culture mehod (Fig. 3).
The analytical sensitivities of the three PCRs were determined following the methods shown in Fig. 1.
The detection limit of C-PCR was found 120 pg/reaction (3 × 104 copies/reaction), while N-PCR and Q-PCR assays could detect as few as 0.012 pg/reaction (3 copies/reaction; Ct = 37) (Fig. 2).

N-PCR and Q-PCR assays using categories (b) and (c) as DNA templates (Fig. 1) showed that detection limits of both the N-PCR and Q-PCR were 42 organisms/ml (Ct = 36.9), which corresponded to 10−7 dilution of S.

Determination of diagnostic performance ability of blood culture, N-PCR and Q-PCR assays considering clinically diagnosed typhoid fever (CDTF) cases (n = 110) positive by any of the test methods as standarda

The distributions of Ct values of 110 samples from CDTF cases were shown in Fig. 3.
The standard curve (Fig. 2b) was used to calculate the bacterial DNA load among the study patients.
The distributions of Ct values of 110 samples from CDTF cases were shown in Fig. 3.
The standard curve (Fig. 2b) was used to calculate the bacterial DNA load among the study patients.
Analytical sensitivities of both N-PCR and Q-PCR assays were similar (3 copies/reaction) (Fig. 2).

Although higher copy number (median, 3160 copies/ml) of bacterial DNA was observed by Q-PCR assay in blood culture negative cases (n = 57), the higher rate (60 %) of antibiotic intake among the study population might lead to negative results in blood culture mehod (Fig. 3).
